R&D, Engineers & Scientists

Max Roser [cite]
OWID presents work from many different people and organizations. When citing this entry, please also cite the original data source. This entry can be cited as:

Max Roser (2016) – ‘R&D, Engineers & Scientists’. Published online at OurWorldInData.org. Retrieved from: https://ourworldindata.org/research-development-engineers-scientists/ [Online Resource]

# Empirical View

# Laboratory foundations by sector in the US, pre-1899 – 1946 – unknown source1

# Investment in Research and Development (R&D)

GERD is the abbreviation of gross domestic expenditure on research and development.

BERD is the abbreviation of business investment on research and development.

# U.S. total R&D expenditures in billions of dollars, 1953-2009 – National Science Board (2012)2

# Expenditure on R&D as percentage of gross national product in UK, US, Japan, Germany and France, 1964, 1971, 1978 and 1989 – unknown source3

# Gross expenditures on R&D as share of gross domestic product for selected countries, 1981-2009 – National Science Board (2012)4

# Business investment on research and development as a share of gross domestic product (%) for selected countries, 2000-2007 – UNESCO (2010)5

# Gross domestic expenditure on research and development as a share of gross domestic product (%) in China, 2000-2008 – UNESCO (2010)6

 

Wikipedia has a list of countries by research and development spending with both absolute expenditure and expenditure relative to gross domestic product (GDP).

# Researchers and Engineers

# Researchers per million population and gross domestic expenditure on R&D as share of GDP, 2007 – UNESCO (2010)7

The World Bank has data on Researchers in R&D (per million people).

# Employment of scientists and engineers per 1000 wage earners by industrial sector, 1921-1985 – unknown source8

# Scientists and engineers engaged in R&D per 10,000 workers, 1965, 1972, 1981 and 1987 – unknown source9

# Key indicators on world researchers, 2002 and 2007 – UNESCO (2010)10

# Researchers per thousand employed, full-time equivalent – OECD (2013)11

# Education in Science and Technology (S&T)

# Bachelor’s degrees earned in selected S&T fields in the USA, 1985-2005 – UNESCO (2010)12

# Number of students in engineering sciences and mathematics in Germany (First Semester), 1975-2011 – Wikipedia13

 

Footnotes

  1. The original source is unknown to me; my source are the lecture slides for the course on Economic History at the University of Oxford (2013) by Robert Allen.

    If you know the source please contact me.

  2. The source is National Science Board (2012) – Science and Engineering Indicators 2012. Arlington VA: National Science Foundation (NSB 12-01).

     

    The report is online here.

  3. The original source is unknown to me; my source are the lecture slides for the course on Economic History at the University of Oxford (2013) by Robert Allen.

    If you know the source please contact me.

  4. The source is National Science Board (2012) – Science and Engineering Indicators 2012. Arlington VA: National Science Foundation (NSB 12-01).

     

    The report is online here.

  5. The source is UNESCO (2010) UNESCO Science Report 2010.

     

    The report is online here.

  6. The source is UNESCO (2010) UNESCO Science Report 2010.

     

    The report is online here.

  7. The source is UNESCO (2010) UNESCO Science Report 2010.

     

    The report is online here.

  8. The original source is unknown to me; my source are the lecture slides for the course on Economic History at the University of Oxford (2013) by Robert Allen.

    If you know the source please contact me.

  9. The original source is unknown to me; my source are the lecture slides for the course on Economic History at the University of Oxford (2013) by Robert Allen.

    If you know the source please contact me.

  10. The source is UNESCO (2010) UNESCO Science Report 2010.

     

    The report is online here.

  11. The source is the OECD Factbook 2013.
    The source is online here.

  12. The source is UNESCO (2010) UNESCO Science Report 2010.

     

    The report is online here.

  13. The source of this is Wikipedia here, and I have translated the German original.

Our World in Data

Our World in Data is an online publication by Max Roser which explores the development of human living conditions at a global scale. Our work is licensed under CC BY-SA and freely usable by everyone (including journalists, authors, bloggers, lecturers, or educators).

We are supported by the generous donations of readers. Without these donations our work would not be possible. Thank you!

OWID is developed at the Oxford Martin School:

OWID is also supported by INET Oxford:

And the Nuffield Foundation:

The Nuffield Foundation is an endowed charitable trust that aims to improve social well-being in the widest sense. It has funded this project, but the views expressed are those of the authors and not necessarily those of the foundation.
